data.title: Smurfit Westrock: Market Overreaction And Q3 Resilience (Rating Upgrade)
data.description:
With Smurfit Westrock Plc (SW) down ~11% at the time of writing, we see a strong buying opportunity. We anticipated volume pressure after Mondi’s profit warning, and Q3 North American volumes fell 8.7% compared with PKG, which was down by 2.7%. International Paper also reported its numbers with a small volume decline. Given the soft 3Q and the recent share-price slide, a cautious Q4 outlook is largely priced in.

Having said that, we continue to see upside in Smurfit Westrock given a valuation discount, operational synergies with improving margin in North America with restructuring and asset optimization, global footprint to mitigate tariffs, and a potential peace ahead (between Ukraine and Russia) with potentially lower COGS. Additionally, as already reported many times, the company is underpinned by a solid M&A track record and strong execution.

Q3 Results

Smurfit Westrock Q3 sales and adjusted EBITDA reached $8 billion and $1.3 billion, respectively. Top-line sales were up 1% and 4% quarterly and yearly. The company adjusted its EBITDA margin to 16.3% in Q3 (Fig. 1).

Source: Smurfit Westrock Q3 results ppt - Fig 2

On a regional basis, the company's main impact was related to lower volumes in the North American region, while LatAm and the EU were slightly up (Fig. 2). Going to the cash flow, operating cash amounted to $1.13 billion, with FCF at $523 million. FCF was up +70% quarterly. This was backed by a higher working capital release of $171 million, which offset the higher CAPEX. Diluted EPS came in at $0.47, including impairment and restructuring costs of $65 million. This restructuring activity charge was $280 million in Q2.

Fig 3

Our Upside Case

All told, we see this as a market overreaction.

Value Over Volume Strategy Ongoing

Indeed, the company is losing volume in North America, but the market is down by 3-4%. So, Smurfit Westrock attributes 50 basis points of its decline to the value-over-volume strategy. The company is progressing in shutting down production capacity linked to non-performing mills and has already closed three paper mills. Indeed, top management reported: "further reduction in the number of corrugated loss makers and continuing rationalization of inefficient capacity." The adjusted EBITDA margin of 17.2% is a positive sign. More importantly, Smurfit Westrock's adjusted EBITDA accelerated on a quarterly basis, signing a plus +7% versus +3% yearly.

Supportive Synergies Ahead

On a negative note, the company reduced its fiscal year 2025 adjusted EBITDA guidance to $4.9–5.1 billion (compared to a previous indication range of $5-5.2 billion - Fig. 4). This implied an adjusted EBITDA of $1.23 billion in Q4 2025 at the midpoint. Still, the company remains on track to deliver $400 million in synergies. During the analyst's call, top management explained that the cut is related to the weak US demand and higher maintenance ($180-200 million versus last year).

Fig 4

Global Footprint As A Key Differentiator

As a global leader with a footprint in the EU and LatAm, the company benefits from diversification. The company's press release very well supports this: "We believe we are one of the market leaders in EMEA and APAC, where we have once again demonstrated good returns despite a difficult market backdrop to deliver Adjusted EBITDA of $419 million with an Adjusted EBITDA margin of 14.8%." EU mills are operating at a full utilization rate. The company also disclosed its 2026 CAPEX guidance before the year-end. This is unusual, but we see a positive take here. 2026 CAPEX is estimated to be close to consensus guidance at ~$2.4 billion. Still, on a positive note, the company confirmed its quarterly dividend payment of $0.4308 per share (Fig. 5).

Fig 5

Valuation

Here at the Lab, we are deliberately not modeling a volume recovery or improved synergies in 2026. We had previously set 2025 EBITDA at $5 billion, which is now consistent with management’s estimates. We were not insensitive to Mondi's profit warning, so we incorporated short-term challenges, but this share price evolution supports doubling down on our entry price. We apply no change to our EV/EBITDA target multiple (8x), so Smurfit Westrock's enterprise value reached $40 billion. Our EV/EBITDA is below Packaging Corp. of America's and Smurfit Kappa's valuation before the merger with Westrock. Additionally, our target price is below the sector median with a TTM EBITDA of 9.99x (Fig. 6). Considering the current financial obligation, the company's equity value reached $26.5 billion. This represents approximately a 35% upside. There is also a 4.5% dividend yield, which is a total return estimate of almost 40% in one year.

Fig 6

Risks

The company is subject to similar risks as the rest of the paper and packaging sector, such as FX changes (which are relevant given Smurfit Westrock's US industrial footprint and its euro reporting), declining consumer activity given a potential economic slowdown, COGS price changes (raw materials, energy prices, and chemicals), wage inflation, changes in packaging trends, and overcapacity. Supply-demand imbalance is a common downside risk across the sector. Additionally, given the recent merger, Smurfit Westrock is also exposed to integration risks and lower combined synergies. Having said that, the company has a solid track record in M&A.

Conclusion

The Q3 print and call commentary reinforced our positive thesis. We’re surprised by the adverse share reaction and are upgrading Smurfit to a Strong Buy Recommendation. This call is not only based on a discounted valuation, but rather on the best opportunity to invest in what we consider the best-managed company in the paper sector.

Editor's Note: This article discusses one or more securities that do not trade on a major U.S. exchange. Please be aware of the risks associated with these stocks.

data.title: Verra Mobility Corp.: Solid Visibility Into Long-Term Growth
data.description:
Investment Overview

I wrote about Verra Mobility Corp. (VRRM) previously with a buy rating, as the business outlook remains positive, and given the valuation has become cheaper, I stayed bullish. For this update, I maintain a buy rating. My view is still that this is a strong, well-managed business that is seeing fundamentals improving. VRRM has won the NYCDOT contract, which removes a huge uncertainty in the equity story. With new potential growth levers like new legislation changes in California, I would think VRRM is still in very good shape to grow for the foreseeable future.

3Q25 Earnings

The Q3 2025 results were very strong. VRRM’s total revenue grew 16% y/y to $262 million, coming in way ahead of consensus. The beat was almost entirely driven by Government Solutions [GS], which saw 28% y/y growth. The key catalyst was the timing and pull-forward of the New York City contract. In Q3, VRRM booked $17 million of revenue tied to a New York City Department of Transportation [NYCDOT] change order to install up to 250 additional red-light cameras in 2025. In that $17 million, it included $6 million from product sales. Remember that I’ve discussed this previously, noting this as a growth catalyst. It has surely played out nicely and as expected. For the Commercial Services [CS] segment, revenue grew 7% y/y to $117.3 million. The 3% decline in Fleet Management [FMC] was expected, as the customer churn was already disclosed in Q2 2024.

In terms of profit, adj. EBITDA grew 8% y/y to $113 million. This was below revenue growth because of one-time readiness costs tied to the NYC expansion. Some of the major cost items include developing a real-time camera health dashboard, cloud migration, and getting more subcontractor capacity onboard. These are necessary upfront investments to make sure VRRM is ready to win demand (like the $963 million contract opportunity), and hence, they shouldn’t be considered as recurring costs. Anyway, despite the heavier spend, adj. EPS still grew 16% y/y to $0.37.

The NYC Overhang Is Gone

The outcome of the NYCDOT RFP was a very bullish moment for VRRM’s equity story. As I said before, this was an important growth catalyst, which could also be seen as an overhang (investors don’t like uncertainty). Thankfully, that uncertainty is now gone, and VRRM has been officially awarded the contract. What makes this even better than it seems is that this is not just a simple renewal. It is actually a large expansion contract with multi-year visibility. Here are the terms of the deal: the VRRM contract is on a five-year term with a five-year renewal option. In other words, VRRM has effectively locked in its largest customer for potentially a decade. The total estimated value for the initial term alone is $963 million. For perspective, VRRM's entire FY2024 revenue is only $879 million.

The scope of this deal is also very positive for VRRM. It includes the sale and installation of ~1,000 additional red-light and fixed bus-lane cameras over the next 2+ years. This matters for two reasons. First, it gives VRRM a sizeable sum of front-loaded, high-margin product revenue (NYCDOT has chosen to purchase the equipment directly from VRRM), which management expects will contribute $20 million to $30 million in product revenue in both 2026 and 2027. Second, and more importantly, this permanently expands the VRRM recurring revenue base. Each of these 1,000 cameras represents a long-term service stream that generates visible, high-margin revenue. Basically, the installed base has gotten significantly larger, and a larger installed base means more recurring revenue. Given this win, I think the GS segment can very easily grow high-single-digit to low-double-digit service revenue through the foreseeable future.

Execution, Balance Sheet, And Growth Momentum

Beyond the NYC contract win, the rest of VRRM business continues to execute exceptionally well too. The CS segment continues to operate steadily, maintaining its status as the cash-generative engine for VRRM. In Q3, revenue grew 7% y/y, supported by a 7% increase in rental-car tolling activity. The key data point here is that TSA passenger traffic grew by only 1% in Q3, which means the growth was not a boost from higher travel-related passengers. This reliable cash flow provides VRRM the flexibility to deleverage quickly (net leverage is now down to just 2x). On this balance sheet topic, management has refinanced the term loan, extending its maturity by seven years to 2032 and cutting the spread by 25 bps. The focus here on balance sheet matters to some extent because the NYC contract win is good, but it requires heavy investments. The last thing we want to see is VRRM being put in a difficult position where it needs to raise debt or equity to fund this growth capex.

Growth momentum in GS, which I highlighted in my last update, is also accelerating. Specifically, for California’s speed camera program, which was still in its six-city pilot phase previously, VRRM has won its third award, with San Jose confirming its intent to award. With this win, it marks VRRM's third win following the deals in San Francisco and Oakland. You can start to see this trend forming nicely, that as VRRM wins more deals, it makes it more credible in the industry. Every win becomes a reference point for the next deal. I would love to think that this is the case, and if true, we should continue to see VRRM winning deals on this front.

Winning these deals is not just good for the financial benefits, but also because VRRM gains a “priority” seat when it comes to more services needed. Take the recent California legislation, for instance. The new legislation doesn’t just require a new work-zone speed pilot but also a complete restructuring of California’s red-light program, moving it from criminal to civil enforcement. This is huge because the 'criminal' term was a major operating barrier; in a sense, it was a political headache for cities to adopt due to high fines and the related legal process for drivers. This new change shifts the status from criminal to a simple civil penalty (just think of this like a parking ticket). This makes the program far easier to adopt for municipalities (they don’t need to go through the high hurdles of passing a “criminal law”), and this, in my view, should significantly accelerate adoption. For VRRM, because it is already in contract with California, it should naturally be the vendor of choice.

Valuation

My updated model still suggests attractive upside for VRRM. My growth assumptions are the same: that revenue growth should continue to compound at a high single-digit percentage given the new NYC contract win and expanding opportunities in California and potentially other states. In fact, my growth assumption may be too low, but for conservatism's sake, I will stick to 8%. I have delayed VRRM achieving a 25% adj. earnings margin by 1 year to FY28 to reflect the heavy investments required for the NYC deal. One new change to the model is I am pricing in share buybacks. So far into FY2025, VRRM has already bought back 3% of shares, and I assume this to continue as VRRM has the balance sheet strength to continue. This gives us an FY28 adj. EPS of $2.05. Multiplying that by 18x forward PE (VRRM historical average multiple), I think VRRM shares can be worth $37 by FY2027.

Risk

The main risk is from the front-loaded margin pressure from the new NYC contract. Management expects to see some margin pressure in 2026, and should the required expenses go beyond expectations, the unit economics of this contract may not be as lucrative. The deal also increases customer concentration risk. In Q3 2025, NYCDOT accounted for 19.5% of total revenue, and the top three CS clients represented more than 38%. Should any of them churn, for any reason, it would be detrimental for VRRM.

Conclusion

I reiterate a buy rating for VRRM. I believe VRRM’s fundamentals have gotten a lot better after the NYC contract award, one that enables it to lock in its largest customer for the next decade. The balance sheet is stronger, cash flow remains robust, and new legislative tailwinds are potentially expanding VRRM’s addressable market. While 2026 will see near-term margin pressure from upfront costs, I believe these investments will support higher growth and profitability in 2027 and beyond.

data.title: BJ's Restaurants Is Still Becoming More Efficient (Rating Downgrade)
data.description:
My thesis for investing in BJ’s Restaurants (BJRI) is that it is making its restaurants more efficient, so its bottom line can still grow even if it doesn’t add new locations in the near future. And I expect its margins to grow faster than analysts expect, which means that the stock is potentially undervalued based on earnings multiples. Additionally, BJ’s can use its increased income to drive EPS growth in other ways, such as stock buybacks.

I discussed this thesis in my previous article about BJ’s, but my call may have been too early. I recommended buying the stock at $35 per share in August, and its closing price on October 30 was $29. It appears that investors liked the third-quarter report, and after it came out, BJ’s stock price rose to $31 in post-market trading. But it might still take more time for this stock to rise back to $35.

In its third-quarter report, BJ’s reported 0.5% same-store sales growth and 1.4% overall revenue growth. It also reported $330.2 million in revenue and $0.04 in adjusted diluted EPS. It’s maintaining its guidance for 2% same-store sales growth for the full year of 2025, and early fourth-quarter trends are promising. Its third-quarter results were weaker than expected, but the restaurant does have a good explanation for this. It was facing tougher comps because of the launch of the Pizookie Meal Deal last year. But first, I’ll take a look at BJ’s margins.

BJ’s Margins Are Still Growing

My investment thesis for BJ’s depends on margin expansion, and BJ’s did report additional margin growth during the third quarter. Its restaurant-level operating margin rose from 11.7% in the third quarter of 2024 to 12.5% in the third quarter of 2025. Its adjusted EBITDA margin also improved to 6.4% in the third quarter.

The restaurant’s unadjusted bottom-line results also improved. It posted an unadjusted loss of $2.9 million in the third quarter of 2024, and an unadjusted profit of $465 million in the third quarter of 2025. It was only able to post positive GAAP net income because of tax benefits, though. It reported an EBIT of -$999 million. Either way, BJ’s is becoming more efficient right now, so that part of the thesis still holds up.

Full-Year 2025 Forecast

BJ’s maintained its guidance for 2% same-store sales growth for the full year in the earnings report, but didn’t provide overall revenue guidance. Because the company’s revenue growth as a whole has been slightly higher than its same-store sales growth, I’d estimate that its full-year revenue could rise 3% to $1.398 billion for the full year of 2025. I don’t expect it to add any new locations in the fourth quarter of 2025.

In the third-quarter earnings report, BJ’s said that its revenue for the first three quarters of 2025 was $1.044 billion. So, using the company’s full-year guidance, I can estimate that its fourth-quarter 2025 revenue will be $354 million. Its guidance also called for $136 million in full-year adjusted EBITDA at the midpoint, and with $1.398 billion in revenue, that’s a 9.7% margin. So, with $354 million in revenue, its fourth-quarter adjusted EBITDA would be $34 million.

Pizookies Are Still The Growth Driver for BJ’s

While BJ’s posted weaker top-line results this quarter, this wasn’t just because of economic weakness. BJ’s introduced the Pizookie Meal Deal in the third quarter of 2024, so it was facing a tougher-than-usual comparison. This $13 lunch deal includes both an entree and a Pizookie, a cookie topped with ice cream. And it’s the reason why BJ’s still has positive traffic growth right now. On the call, management said that traffic growth drove the restaurant’s same-store sales growth in the third quarter. Its average check size isn’t increasing and might have dropped a bit.

This restaurant also offers seasonal Pizookie treats, such as the Spooky Pizookie, which was originally introduced in 2023 and has now been brought back for 2025. On the call, management also said that BJ’s has more seasonal Pizookies coming up in the fourth quarter, including the Monkey Bread Pizookie and a new Dubai Chocolate Pizookie.

Falling Alcohol Demand Is Still a Risk for BJ’s

Like other restaurants, BJ’s has raised its prices in 2025. In the third quarter, its prices were up 2% in comparison to last year. But that didn’t translate into growth in average check size, and one reason for that was because consumers ordered fewer alcoholic beverages. In my previous article, I mentioned that many younger consumers were avoiding alcohol and ordering treats like cookies instead, and that hasn't changed. BJ’s has an on-trend alternative with its Pizookies, but falling demand for alcohol is still a risk factor for the restaurant.

The AI Scheduling Software Has Not Been Fully Rolled Out Yet

In my last article about BJ’s Restaurants, I explained that the company was using AI scheduling software to reduce its labor costs. It’s using AI to forecast traffic and then using these forecasts to create schedules for its employees. In addition to reducing costs, the AI software could also deliver incremental revenue growth because the restaurant will be able to schedule more employees during peak hours.

While this software has already helped BJ’s become more efficient, the company hasn’t fully rolled out this AI scheduling software yet. Management explained that 30% of BJ’s locations would be using the software by the end of 2025. So this software isn’t just driving current margin expansion, it’s also likely to produce additional margin growth in 2026 as it gets installed at more restaurants.

Updated Valuation For BJ’s

I used a different valuation method for BJ’s in my previous article than I’ve been using in my more recent articles. So, in this article, I’ll also recalculate what I expect its share price to be in 2026. Earlier in this article, I estimated that BJ’s would report $1.398 billion in revenue for the full year of 2025. It guided for $136 million in adjusted EBITDA, which is a 9.7% adjusted EBITDA margin.

It sounds like the third quarter’s results were weaker than usual because of last year’s Pizookie Meal Deal launch, and preliminary fourth-quarter results are better. So I’ll project that BJ’s reports 2% same-store sales growth and 3% overall revenue growth in 2026. BJ’s has around 200 restaurants right now. On the call, management said that BJ’s might add two new locations in the second half of 2026, so I’d also add 0.5% revenue growth because of that factor. With 3.5% revenue growth in 2026, BJ’s revenue would rise to $1.447 billion. And with a 9.7% EBITDA margin, its EBITDA would be $140 million.

After the market close on October 30, but before its post-market rally after earnings came out, BJ’s had a forward EV/EBITDA of 8.31. This was below the 10.39 median for the consumer discretionary sector. If BJ’s had a 2026 EV/EBITDA of 9 and an EBITDA of $140 million, its EV would be $1.26 billion. If you subtract $478 million in debt and add $26 million in cash, its market cap would be $808 million in 2026.

BJ’s has also reduced its diluted share count from 23.8 million to 23.4 million this year with share buybacks, and it’s planning to buy back more shares. So I’d estimate that it will have 23.0 million shares in 2026. With a market cap of $808 million and 23.0 million shares, my new target price for BJ’s would be $35 per share in 2026. On October 30, its closing price was $29 per share, but its post-market price after its earnings report came out was $31 per share. So, my target price is 13% higher than the post-market price.

Conclusion

BJ’s still has several growth drivers, such as its Pizookie Meal Deal and its limited-time, seasonal Pizookies. And it did face tougher comps this quarter. So, I think it will still report rising sales in 2026, but might not grow as fast as I originally expected, and that means its earnings won’t grow as fast as I expected either. Additionally, I also changed the valuation method I was using since I wrote my last article on BJ’s, but its stock price has fallen since then as well. At a price of $31, I still think it’s a buy.

data.title: These REITs Could Outperform The Vanguard Real Estate ETF
data.description:
The Vanguard Real Estate Index Fund ETF Shares (VNQ) is commonly viewed as the benchmark for REITs.

It is the largest and best diversified real estate ETF with $65 billion of assets under management, holding stakes across most major REITs.

However, as I have discussed in past articles, it has many flaws, one of which is that it invests across all property sectors, including those that are facing severe headwinds.

Offices are feeling the pain from the growing trend of remote and hybrid work, which has pushed vacancy rates to all-time highs.

Hotels are suffering growing competition from Airbnb (ABNB), even as Zoom (ZM) has permanently reduced business travel, and booking websites are taking an ever-rising share of the revenue.

Malls are also being impacted by the growth of e-commerce, which we only expect to accelerate as a result of the AI revolution, as it will make online marketing a lot more powerful.

And these are just a few examples, but there are many others.

My point is that there are large sub-segments of the REIT market that are structurally unattractive, and yet, these ETFs hold large allocations to them, which we expect to hurt their performance over the long run.

I would much rather screen out these struggling property sectors and focus instead on specialty assets that enjoy superior fundamentals and have a history of beating the market.

In what follows, I am going to give you three good examples of that to illustrate how easy it can be to beat REIT sector averages:

VICI Properties Inc. (VICI)

For a long time, VICI Properties was one of our largest holdings at High Yield Landlord. We invested so heavily in it because we thought that its unique focus on casino net lease properties had the potential to deliver market-beating returns.

Now looking back, we can see that it has earned over 3x higher returns than the Vanguard Real Estate Index Fund ETF Shares since going public:

It was so much more rewarding because it had a unique strategy, targeting specialty net lease assets that were, until recently, ignored by most other investors.

While Realty Income (O) and others were targeting traditional net lease properties such as Dollar General (DG) convenience stores and Walgreens pharmacies, VICI was structuring off-market sale and leaseback transactions to purchase major casinos such as the Venetian on the Las Vegas Strip.

The relative lack of competition for these assets allowed it to secure higher cap rates and better lease terms than the risk profile of these properties would otherwise justify.

It resulted in strong growth and significant value creation as it consolidated the casino net lease sector, earning large spreads over its cost of capital.

What About Today?

Now the REIT is a lot larger in size, and new competitors have emerged, which will likely slow down its growth going forward.

Therefore, I would not expect it to earn 3x higher returns than the broader REIT market any longer.

However, I would still expect it to outperform over time because the REIT owns a well-diversified portfolio of trophy casino properties in prime locations, and its leases are superior to those of its peers.

  • Its lease escalations are a lot greater.
  • Its lease terms are a lot longer.
  • Its leases force tenants to reinvest in their properties, and VICI bears zero capex responsibility.

This provides a strong base to earn highly consistent cash flow with predictable growth, which, coupled with even a limited number of acquisitions, should allow the REIT to keep earning double-digit annual total returns going forward, given that it is already offering a near 6% dividend yield.

Therefore, the risk-to-reward remains very attractive, and we expect more outperformance over the long run.

Sun Communities, Inc. (SUI)

Sun Communities is another REIT with a unique strategy that has resulted in significant long-term outperformance:

Instead of targeting single-family rentals or apartment communities like most other real estate investors, it is targeting manufactured housing communities and RV parks.

These assets enjoy many advantages that have historically resulted in superior returns.

First, as the landlord, you typically only own the land and associated infrastructure of these communities. Your tenants then rent the individual sites and buy their own homes, which means that they also need to pay for their own maintenance.

Second, because it is impractical and expensive to move a home from one community to another, tenants will typically stay for a very long time, and landlords have greater pricing power in enforcing rent hikes.

Third, affordable housing is always in high and growing demand, yet the new supply of such properties is strictly limited by restrictive municipal approvals. No one wants a new manufactured housing community in their backyard, and this is resulting in a permanent supply-demand imbalance that favors landlords and results in superior rent growth:

The REIT just recently sold its marina business to Blackstone (BX), which allowed it to pay off a bunch of debt and refocus on its best assets.

I think that this only makes the case stronger, and therefore, I expect Sun Communities to keep outperforming over the long run.

CubeSmart (CUBE)

CubeSmart is one of the leading self-storage REITs, and it has also beaten market averages over time:

Self-storage is uniquely attractive for REITs because it is a property sector in which scale can be a major competitive advantage.

It can allow you to build valuable brands, pay for national advertising campaigns, and implement sophisticated revenue optimization models, which may not be available to smaller, less sophisticated landlords.

You just cannot afford to pay for a nationwide TV and billboard ad campaign when you own just one or a few properties.

It provides an opportunity for self-storage REITs like CubeSmart to acquire properties from less sophisticated landlords, change brands, and improve operations in order to quickly boost revenue and create a lot of value.

Going forward, I expect this outperformance to continue as valuations are today historically low in this property sector, and the AI revolution has the potential to greatly boost the demand going forward.

I expect it to lead to significant labor market disruption, which has historically been one of the strongest demand drivers as people move from one place to another and/or seek to downsize their homes and offices.

Moreover, it could also lead to a boom in new small business formation, as AI is making it easier than ever before to start almost any type of business. These new small business owners won't rent large warehouses. They will turn to flexible storage space instead.

The market has completely overlooked this narrative so far, which only makes me more bullish in the future.

Closing Note

Not all property sectors are equally attractive, and that is why it is so important to be selective with your REIT investments.

Some traditional property sectors like offices, hotels, and malls are facing severe headwinds, even as other specialty sectors like casinos, manufactured housing, and self-storage enjoy strong tailwinds.

At High Yield Landlord, we have positioned our portfolio in the property sectors that have long histories of market outperformance, and this is one of the key reasons that has allowed us to beat the Vanguard Real Estate ETF over the long run.

data.title: FinVolution Vs. Qfin: Both Undervalued, But Qfin Offers The Bigger Margin Of Safety
data.description:
Introduction

QFIN Holdings (QFIN) and FinVolution Group (FINV) both emerged during China's online lending boom. The increasing demand for quick and easy credit created a lending industry characterized by fraudulent operators and questionable business practices. Years of regulation — which ultimately led to the shutdown of P2P lending in 2021 — forced existing players to change their business models substantially.

QFIN and FINV are now among the largest fintech players in China. And although they both focus on technology-enabled finance, they followed quite divergent paths after the mentioned crackdown. QFIN rebuilt around bank-partnered loan facilitation and technology services, whereas FINV moved toward capital-light, fee-based services with a strong focus on international expansion.

Nevertheless, both companies still generate most of their revenues in China and are therefore heavily dependent on its macroeconomic and regulatory environment. Recently, they were once again affected by new regulatory guidelines for internet-based lending practices. The regulation led to softer company outlooks for H2 2025, followed by sharp declines in share prices. This shift in momentum and slight adjustment to EPS revisions led to a downgrade in their Quant ratings — from Strong Buy to Hold.

At today's depressed valuations, both companies again appear heavily undervalued. In my recent analysis on QFIN, I already concluded that strong shareholder returns and an incredibly cheap valuation make the company an attractive buy.

In this analysis, I want to closely compare both companies' business models, operating efficiency, growth, and risk structures — to identify which is the better buy.

Business Models – Different Paths to Success

The business model of QFIN and FINV is to leverage big data and AI in the financial industry. Both companies are specifically focused on developing products in the lending industry. Their products aim to improve the safety, efficiency, and speed of online lending, covering the whole loan lifecycle, including credit and risk rating, loan pricing, fraud detection, and post-loan management.

FINV operates as a hybrid fintech lender, primarily earning revenue from loan facilitation (matching borrowers with partner banks) & service fees, guarantees, and net interest income.

A small portion of FINV's loan volume is held on its own balance sheet. By doing this, the company is taking the full loan risk in exchange for the whole net interest income.

QFIN also acts as a loan facilitator, earning commissions and service fees. QFIN funds its loans through partner banks, trust investors, or its own capital. It also acts as a guarantor and runs a credit matching platform, connecting borrowers with its partner banks. Further revenue streams are referral fees and technology services. QFIN's management team considers these services an important driver of future capital-light revenue.

A closer look at the most recent revenue breakdown shows how differently QFIN and FINV generate their income.

QFIN's revenue is driven by net interest income — accounting for 42.3% — showing that a significant portion of revenue still comes from interest-bearing activities.

FINV's top line relies mainly on loan facilitation and guarantee income (together 71.7%), confirming its fee-based, capital-light model.

Referral and post-facilitation fees are stronger for QFIN than for FINV.

Both companies generate a similar share of other and tech-related revenue.

Overall, QFIN's model appears more interest-driven and vertically integrated, while FINV's focus lies in diversifying its service-oriented business horizontally.

Key Metrics

The borrower profiles of both companies show some overlap. However, FINV generally targets younger, new-to-credit customers, whereas QFIN focuses on higher-quality borrowers with established credit histories.

Despite similar cumulative borrower counts — 36.6 million for FINV and 36.8 million for QFIN — QFIN facilitates 57% more loan volume and accounts for an 81% larger loan balance.

QFIN's 93.8% repeat borrower share is also higher than FINV's 86.2%, underlining stronger customer retention.

QFIN's average loan size is slightly lower at RMB 8,900 vs. RMB 10,056 for FINV, while the average loan term of QFIN is about two months longer than FINV's 10.3 months vs. 8.2 months.

QFIN's average user acquisition cost is RMB 370 compared with RMB 455 for FINV.

The data imply the following: QFIN manages to integrate its users more deeply into its ecosystem, leading to higher borrowing frequency and engagement. Despite similar borrower counts and growth, and smaller average loan sizes, QFIN generates higher loan volumes and outstanding balances.

FINV's larger but shorter loans generate less cumulative loan activity per borrower, resulting in lower total loan volumes and balances.

Since financial partners fund loan volume, the idea is simple: the more loan volume they facilitate, the more fee income they generate. QFIN's stronger borrower engagement results in lower user acquisition costs, demonstrating its superior operational efficiency compared to FINV.

Geographic & Strategic Focus

QFIN focuses on deepening its operations in China, whereas FINV is following a plan of geographic diversification. 21% of FINV's revenue comes from international operations in Southeast Asian markets, whereas QFIN is still entirely dependent on its revenues from China. However, QFIN recently initiated its international expansion with a pilot project in the U.K. Although the management team recently emphasized its strong commitment to global expansion, it still sees significant opportunities in its local market.

We believe the robust fintech infrastructure this market offers presents significant opportunities for us and are confident that our AI and big data capabilities will create substantial value by addressing underserved local demand. Meanwhile, we are proactively exploring additional international opportunities, and our commitment to global expansion has never been stronger. (QFIN Q2 2025 Earnings Call Transcript)

FINV grows through expansion into higher-margin countries, including the Philippines, Indonesia, and, most recently, Bangladesh. QFIN, on the other hand, grows vertically by focusing on higher-quality, data-rich borrowers, leveraging its advanced technologies and vast relationships with local financial institutions.

Growth Comparison

Both companies have a strong history of top-line growth — and are expected to continue their upward trend.

Analysts estimate revenue CAGRs for 2025 to 2027 of 10.2% for FINV and 7.6% for QFIN. QFIN's revenue growth took a hit in 2022 and slowly recovered since then, while FINV's growth — despite also slowing down — wasn't affected as much. In regard to EPS, analysts estimate CAGRs for 2025 to 2027 of 11.5% for FINV and 14.2% for QFIN.

The net income 3-year CAGR of 12.9% for QFIN and 5.1% for FINV, as well as operating cash flow data, proves that QFIN's growth is more profitable and consistent than FINV's.

The data support the difference in strategic focus. FINV's entrance into new markets drives strong revenue accretion at the cost of earnings quality. QFIN, on the other hand, prioritizes efficient and stable cash generation over aggressive expansion, which it then returns to its shareholders through its massive repurchase programs, leading to strong shareholder returns and EPS accretion.

As of now, FINV's growth optionality appears more tangible, as they have already advanced in their international expansion and recently surpassed an international revenue share of 20%. QFIN, in contrast, hasn't yet captured international markets, and technology services haven't yet contributed significantly to revenue.

FINV's growth strategy comes with higher execution risk due to the exposure to different legal frameworks, a higher fixed cost structure, and a lower borrower quality. However, it likely comes with a bigger long-term potential, as it gives access to high-growth markets, characterized by low fintech penetration rates.

Profitability Comparison

QFIN's margins have been consistently stronger than FINV's. According to their most recent earnings reports, adjusted operating margins were 43.2% for QFIN and 23.9% for FINV.

This is the result of several factors:

First, FINV spends slightly more on loan facilitation, origination, and servicing.

Second, FINV spends around 33% more on sales and marketing.

Third, it seems that FINV is also spending more on G&A and R&D. Although this is not fully verifiable, as QFIN isn't disclosing the financial impact of R&D in its income statements.

Fourth, and certainly the most significant impact on cost efficiency, is the difference in how the companies handle loan risks. FINV provides guarantees to partner banks through its "Quality Assurance (QA)" system. The guarantees require FINV to deposit funds with its partner banks, making sure potential loan losses are covered. Meaning, each guarantee involves real cash outflow, binding FINV's liquidity until loans mature. Additionally, FINV needs to make provisions for further potential loan losses. These two positions account for 27.6% and 5.7% of its revenue. Presumably, FINV follows the practice of larger securities, as it helps the company to build and expand relationships with its financial partners quickly.

QFIN's outstanding efficiency stems from the fact that it solely manages loan risks by making provisions, representing 25.3% of its revenues. Unlike FINV, QFIN doesn't deposit collateral to partner banks. Instead, they are utilizing non-cash provisions, which don't require upfront payments. Cash payments are only required if loan defaults are realized, providing more liquidity to QFIN.

FINV records substantially higher QA and provision expenses, reflecting a more risk-intensive business model.

Cash Efficiency

That also explains why QFIN is doing much better in converting operating income into operating cash flow. Both companies earn income from guarantees and net interest, but FINV consumes far more liquidity to secure it. While QFIN manages credit risk through non-cash provisions that are later released, FINV relies primarily on QA, which requires cash deposits and guarantee payments. As a result, QFIN's operating cash flows remain stable, whereas FINV's fluctuate more.

Risk Management

Both companies maintained excellent risk management over the last years, despite the challenging macroeconomic and regulatory environment. The credit performance of FINV and QFIN remained very stable and almost identical.

Balance Sheet & Shareholder Returns

Both companies maintain healthy balance sheets. QFIN has moderate leverage, with a debt-to-equity ratio of 28%, compared to FINV's extremely low ratio of 7%. QFIN's higher leverage is offset by its more stable cash generation.

Both companies pay semi-annual dividends and have a history of increasing them. As of today, FINV's FWD dividend yield amounts to 4.7%, compared to 6.8% for QFIN. FINV's payout ratio is historically a bit lower, offset by a more stable dividend growth record.

In addition to dividends, FINV and QFIN have consistently returned shareholder value in the past through buybacks. In H1 2025, FINV has repurchased 2.4% of its outstanding shares, compared to 8.4% for QFIN. Both companies have already authorized, but unused, share repurchase volume. Even though FINV is already returning a significant amount of generated cash to its shareholders, QFIN's share repurchase program is even more remarkable. In fact, the company currently has two active buyback programs. A regular one, and an extraordinary one, funded by issuance of convertible senior notes at an extremely low-interest rate of 0.5%.

If FINV were to utilize its remaining share repurchase volume of $89.3 million, the company could retire 12.75 to 14.9 million shares, assuming an average repurchase price of $6.00 to $7.00 per share. This would represent a buyback yield of 5.0 to 5.9%.

QFIN, on the other hand, still has $623 million in already authorized, but unused share repurchase volume. Meaning the company could retire around 25 to 30 million shares, assuming an average repurchase price of $25.00 to $30.00 per share. This would represent a buyback yield of 14.8 to 17.7%

When combining dividends and share repurchases, FINV currently offers a YTD 2025 total shareholder yield of 7.1%. If buybacks were fully utilized, total shareholder yield would reach 12.1 to 13.0%.

QFIN currently offers a YTD 2025 total shareholder yield of 15.2%. If buybacks were fully utilized, total shareholder yield would reach 29.1 to 32.2%.

Today's depressed valuations, operational strength, and clean balance sheets allow both companies to return capital at double-digit yields. QFIN's rate of capital return is unique and represents an exceptional margin of safety for investors.

Valuation Comparison

Both companies trade at extremely low multiples. QFIN is cheaper than FINV on key metrics such as P/E and P/OCF. Despite its excellent cash flow generation and shareholder returns, QFIN only trades at 1.9x its cash flows compared to 4.8x for FINV.

Both companies are heavily discounted vs. their sector, with discounts ranging from 50 to 90% (see data for FINV and QFIN), showcasing the reluctance towards investments in China. Although, even by comparing the valuation metrics against their 5-year averages, both companies clearly show signs of undervaluation. With discounts of 31 to 35% across P/E, P/B, and EV/EBIT, QFIN trades at deeper discounts than FINV, with discounts of 15 to 24%, leaving more room for future multiple re-ratings.

The multi-year P/E chart shows that QFIN is almost trading at its historical lows of 2.5x P/E, whereas FINV still has more room to hit its historical floor.

In summary, QFIN appears more undervalued relative to fundamentals and historical levels.

Risks

Both companies operate in a challenging macroeconomic environment, characterized by weakening home prices, household consumption, and rising youth unemployment.

They also operate under tight Chinese regulation, known for its frequent and unpredictable changes. While the financial performance has been solid over the last years, new regulations and macroeconomic headwinds could continue to affect revenues and margins.

AI-driven risk models heavily rely on data inputs. Any tightening of data privacy regulations could harm the companies' underwriting quality.

Company Specific Risks

FINV faces a broader range of risks, as part of its revenue comes from international operations, which introduce FX and country-specific risks. FINV's focus on younger, first-time borrowers might entail higher risks in the future. The diversification helps FINV to reduce its dependency on China. But it also causes bigger operational costs, which, along with the cash-heavy guarantees, lead to inferior operating margins.

QFIN, in contrast, operates almost entirely in China, making the company fully dependent on domestic regulatory changes. QFIN's income is heavily reliant on net interest income from bank-funding partnerships, making it more sensitive to interest rate changes.

Annual Percentage Rate (APR) CAP reduction

Any shifts, such as the recently widely discussed reduction of maximum APR in China from 24 to 20%, would significantly harm QFIN. All future loans of QFIN would be affected, whereas FINV's international expansion would partly reduce the impact. Lower APRs would compress margins across all consumer loans. Both companies would likely need to tighten their credit risk standards, leading to a contraction in loan volume. Since FINV caters to a riskier borrower group, which is priced at higher average APRs, an APR cap reduction from 24 to 20% would exclude a larger share of existing borrowers than in QFIN. Given that FINV is already operating at tighter margins than QFIN, I believe FINV would experience greater margin pressure in such a scenario. QFIN, on the other hand, might take a bigger revenue hit, as it relies more on net interest income. However, given its strong margins and diversification of revenue mix, I believe its business model would once again be able to overcome these challenges.

Also, it's important to note that only a portion of the loan volume would be affected by the lower ARP cap. QFIN and FINV cooperate with large, regulated financial institutions that likely do not price their loans at the upper limit of 24%, especially for prime and near-prime borrowers. While it's impossible to model the effect of such a scenario — as too much information is missing — I believe negative EPS effects would be at least partly absorbed through future efficiency gains, buybacks, and restructuring of the competitive landscape.

Investor Takeaway - which is the better stock to buy?

QFIN's business model is characterized by remarkable efficiency, profitability, and cash flow generation. The company leverages its repeat borrower base and deep relationships with local financial institutions, allowing predictable revenues and integration of technological products into its ecosystem. A total shareholder yield of more than 15% and a dirt-cheap valuation relative to the sector and its own past offer a significant margin of safety in an uncertain environment. The stock has plenty of room to rerate back to higher multiples, more in line with historical averages. In the meantime, investors are generously paid to wait. Given the share price drop of 30% from my previous article on QFIN, I now upgrade my rating to a Strong Buy.

FINV also represents a fundamentally strong company with a bulletproof balance sheet. The company is consistently growing its top line, supported by its international expansion in high-growth, low-penetration markets. Although its operating margins are improving, cash-backed QA ties up liquidity, turning its 'capital-light' revenues into an actual capital-heavy business. This represents a major difference compared to QFIN's cash-efficient provisions, leading to larger cash flow fluctuations and a lower ability to return capital to shareholders. Nevertheless, given the amount of cash sitting on FINV's balance sheet, I expect more aggressive buybacks in the future. Lastly, FINV's valuation is clearly attractive, but it doesn't offer the same degree of deep discount as QFIN. FINV's history of lower margins, shareholder returns, and a higher valuation suggests a narrower margin of safety, making the stock a more speculative buy currently. Still, for long-term investors — if FINV executes its expansion correctly — the stock offers geographic diversification into attractive markets, reducing dependence on China's environment. I therefore assign a cautious long-term buy rating. More short-sighted investors should wait for catalysts, such as margin improvements, a lighter QA system, an increase in the buyback program, or important macroeconomic changes.

I generally like FINV, and I also own shares of the company. But, based on my understanding of both companies, I believe QFIN is currently the better and less risky investment.

Editor's Note: This article discusses one or more securities that do not trade on a major U.S. exchange. Please be aware of the risks associated with these stocks.

data.title: AXT Rallies On Strong Q3 Results With Higher Demand From Data Centers And AI Computing
data.description:
AXT, Inc. (AXTI) reported Q3 2025 results yesterday after market. The company’s stock price rallied on higher revenue, decreasing net loss, and positive forward outlook. The company’s raw materials and substrates are in high demand from data centers. The stock price has increased 232% over the last twelve months. It is up 284% since I covered the company last August on Seeking Alpha. I continue my rating of a Hold due to overvaluation.

AXT Q3 2025 Results

AXT reported Q3 2025 revenue of $28 million, representing a 55% increase QoQ and an 18% increase YoY. Gross margin was 22.4%, compared to 8.2% QoQ and 24.3% YoY. Gross profit was $6.2 million, representing a 343% increase QoQ and a 9% increase YoY.

Revenue by channel was as follows. Indium phosphide was $13.1 million, driven by data centers and PON. Revenue for indium phosphide increased more than 250% QoQ and represents a three-year high. The increase is due to the company finally receiving its export permits.

Gallium arsenide revenue was $7.5 million, representing a 20% increase QoQ. The company attributed it to higher demand for semi-insulating wafers used in wireless RF devices. Revenue from germanium substrates was $640k. The company’s raw material joint venture earned $6.7 million in revenue.

The company shared a breakdown of revenue by geography and customer profile. Asia Pacific amounted to 87%. Europe represented 12%. North America made up 1% of revenue. Five large customers made up 45.2% of revenue, and two large customers made up more than 10% of revenue.

Operating expenses were $6.7 million, a decrease QoQ and YoY. Operating loss was $384K compared to a loss of $6.1 million QoQ and a loss of $2.6 million YoY. Net loss was $1.2 million compared to a net loss of $6.4 million QoQ and $2.1 million YoY. Cash and cash equivalents were $31.2 million.

The company forecasts strong Q4 results. It expects Q4 revenue between $27 million and $30 million. AXT will fulfill more of its backlog for indium phosphide and gallium arsenide.

The current backlog for indium phosphide is $49 million. Market consensus for Q4 revenue is $27.5 million. The company will report in February.

Current Synergies

Data center applications and AI computing are driving higher demand for indium phosphide. Indium phosphide-based lasers and detectors for high-speed optical connectivity are also driving demand. The company saw historically high revenue for indium phosphide in Q3. The current process for receiving indium phosphide export permits is three months.

The company’s raw materials joint venture reported nominal growth for the quarter. The company reports that new Tier 1 customers are considering their materials for their supply chains. AXT admits that it is a difficult path to navigate for a company to source its materials. AXT says that it is well-positioned to facilitate demand and supply chain issues.

The company foresees increasing demand for its materials due to “massive AI infrastructure build-out” and “data center build-out” in the US and China. It believes that US hyperscalers are using its materials in their data centers.

The most important current synergy for the company is the possibility of it fulfilling its backlog and gaining export permits for Q4.

AXT reported strong financial performance for Q3 2025. Revenue increased, and net loss has greatly improved. Operating expenses have decreased. Revenue has reached a historical high over the last eight quarters. The company expects demand to increase.

Because the company supplies raw materials and substrates for data centers, its stock price has rallied over the last twelve months. Investor sentiment is extremely positive on the sector and anything related to data centers and AI computing.

The price has rallied beyond the fundamental valuation of the company. Although overvalued, there is still room for price growth. Total EV is higher than market cap, which implies that the price could move higher to meet valuation. Forward multipliers, like NTM Total EV / Revenues, imply that the price is approaching, if not exceeding, fair valuation.

In my last article about AXT, I said that the price could reach $4 per share. It doubled that amount, but the price is now overvalued. Caution is advised.
