AXT and its peers have seen their stock prices increase over the last twelve months. Each company provides hardware and software support for data centers. The sector has undergone a constant rally over AI computing and an increase in data centers globally.

AXT and Applied Optoelectronics are unique compared to their peers because they provide raw materials and substrates for optical networks, like data centers. AAOI also makes optical switches. Both companies provide materials for other products besides data centers. CommScope Holdings, Cisco Systems, and NETGEAR provide hardware and software for data centers and other network solutions, like home and business. AXT has its largest footprint in China and Asia, while the other companies supply North America.

AXT is underperforming compared to its peers. CommScope Holdings and Applied Optoelectronics are outperforming their peers. The stock prices are overvalued across the board, and some analysts worry about an AI and data center bubble. The stock prices have been increasing, and caution is advised.

Investment Strategy and Risk

AXT is at low risk of poor financial performance. The only exception concerns the situation around export permits for its backlog. The company has made progress on the issue. Otherwise, the company sees widespread adoption of its substrate and raw materials into the supply chain for data centers. The company has firm plans to capture this growth.

A Hold rating for AXT comes at a moderate risk. The stock price has rallied and could sink again. The long-term outlook remains good for the company. Their products are in demand, and the sector is experiencing positive sentiment. Compared to its peers, the company trades at a discount.

Conclusion

AXT reported strong financial results for Q3 2025 and expects in-line results for Q4. The company is in the process of processing its backlog as it gains export permits for its substrate and raw materials. AXT foresees high demand for its products to continue to increase. The stock price has rallied over the last twelve months and seems a bit overvalued. I continue my rating of a Hold for the company.

data.title: Travelzoo: The Hidden Growth Story Behind Margin Compression
data.description:
Recommendation

I recommend TravelZoo (TZOO) a buy with a 3-year horizon. My conviction lies in TZOO's good fundamentals and market mispricing on its poor margins. The company is fundamentally stronger as it has improved in quality from its ability to increase operating margin from 2022 till 2024 and is working to monetize its free membership base. Moreover, TZOO has negative net debt and has high insider ownership with the Bartel family's stake (36.7%) in page 10 of the Q2 quarterly report, aligning with minority shareholders. I set a 3-year target price of $24, with ~15x as my exit multiple for 2027E earnings at $1.60 EPS. I believe this to be conservative and would also imply IRR > 60%, which more than compensates for the micro-cap risk.

Q2-Q3 2025 Earnings Commentary

TZOO's Q2 and Q3 2025 results together reflect a consistent pattern of solid top-line growth paired with intentional, margin-compressing investments in its paid membership transition. In Q2, revenue grew 13% year-over-year to $23.9mil which was led by strong growth in both North American and European segments and a 33% revenue increase from Jack's Flight Club. Membership fee income also surged to $3.0mil, up from $1.2mil last year. However, operating income has dropped to $2.1mil from $4.0mil due to higher market and acquisition costs as the company aggressively acquired new paying customers.

By Q3 2025, the reinvestment trend continued: revenue rose 10% to $22.2mil while operating profit dipped to $0.5mil as TZOO accelerated its club member acquisition strategy. Management disclosed payback per member remains positive within a quarter. The higher membership fees ($3.6mil in Q3 report, page 9) confirm that the reinvestment is working and driving future revenue visibility.

In Q3, Jack's Flight Club remained profitable and delivered 12% revenue growth. Cash flow from operations was -$0.4mil due to reducing merchant payables and the company did buybacks of 148k shares. I think this quarter continues to be transitional and constructive rather than structurally bad.

Investment Thesis

TZOO is transitioning from an advertising business model to a subscription travel club, which would unlock recurring revenue and deepen membership loyalty. I believe the market has not yet appreciated this transition and is mispricing TZOO due to short-term earnings compression and its micro-cap profile. The market has overlooked a combination of positive factors: an inflecting membership base, significant operating leverage, and aggressive share buybacks.

What the market has missed?

Membership Inflection: TZOO's shift to a paid membership since 2024 was transformational, but the market doesn't give full credit. In fact, TZOO has gained ~225,000 paying members in Sep-2025 based on $9.0mil deferred revenue (based on an annual membership fee of $40). This gain would provide recurring revenue, which would be recognized in subsequent quarters. Moreover, the unit economics are also very attractive. In Q3 2025, TZOO spent ~$40 to acquire a new member (page 5 of Q3 Investor Presentation), but they would earn ~$55 within the same quarter. This means that there is already a positive LTV/CAC in the first quarter. Subsequent cost would be minimal as the member is already inside the ecosystem while contributing to its revenue.

This is where the market got it wrong. They see the big marketing expense as a negative, causing EPS to decline. But they did not recognize the future incremental benefits. This means that TZOO is building a subscription annuity, which should warrant a higher multiple.

Earnings Masked: The market considers TZOO as a no-earnings-growth company, as diluted EPS has dropped from $1.06 to $0.66 from 2024 to TTM Q3 2025. However, I see it as a trough earnings situation, as its true earnings potential is hidden. TZOO is essentially reinvesting into the business by increasing marketing expenses, and that increases paying membership count. Moreover, the business is also structurally higher margin, as in 2024, its operating margin is ~22% compared to 2022 at ~11%. Once the company has amassed a substantial number of paying customers, it would be difficult for the market to ignore it anymore, leading to a positive re-rating.

Buybacks and Insider Alignment: The market also has not fully accounted for the buybacks the company has done, as the total shares outstanding is ~8% less than last year. Moreover, the company has such a small float, and any institutional accumulation would move the stock significantly upwards.

Valuation

I value TZOO at different angles. On a forward P/E basis, the company is trading around 10.5x, where its sector median is 14.3x and its five-year average is at 18.2x, which is a 42% discount. Moreover, on a forward EV/EBITDA basis, the company is trading around 6.9x, where its sector median is 8.3x. Thus, we can clearly say that the company is traded at a discount compared to its peer group and on a historical basis.

Comparing the forward EV/EBITDA of specific names like Booking Holdings (16.8x), Expedia (8.7x), TZOO's forward EV/EBITDA looks dirt cheap. On a price/FCF basis, using TZOO's TTM FCF at $10.8mil and having ~90mil market cap, this expresses a P/FCF of 8.3x, implying a 12% FCF yield. I would consider this an opportunity to accumulate at this level. Moreover, TZOO is still growing, but the stock is trading at distressed levels.

Therefore, by traditional metrics, TZOO appears undervalued. The likely reason it is trading at severe discounts to peers is because of its small-size and the short-term EPS decline. However, once the company is able to demonstrate earnings power, its multiple should expand rapidly.

Bull & Bear Cases:

Bull case: By 2027, assuming TZOO accumulated 700k paying members (~2.3% of its free base) with $50 ARPU, which would lead to $35mil subscription revenue ($50*700k). An ARPU of $50 is a conservative estimate, as a paying customer would already have an estimated $55 by the first quarter. Moreover, every quarter would have an estimated $15 ARPU, leading to an annualized ARPU of $60 per year. Thus, I used $50 as ARPU in my revenue calculation for conservative purposes.

Next, advertising revenue could also expand to $85mil as more members are added, increasing its negotiation power for higher ad revenue. Thus, by 2027, this would add up to $120mil annual revenue ($85mil + $35mil) and with 20% operating margin due to scale and lower marketing costs, EBIT would be around $24mil. Net margins may expand to 15%, implying $1.6 EPS with 11 million shares outstanding after shares buyback. At a 15x multiple, the company would have a target price of $24, which is ~3x of the current price. Moreover, as the company is small, there is also the catalyst of a private takeover or acquisition by a larger travel company.

Bear case: In a bearish scenario, its plan to monetize and convert its free customer base may not be as successful, and as macro conditions worsen, its revenue would falter. With only the ability to accumulate up to 500k paying customers, this would only lead to $25mil revenue (500k*$50) with $50 as ARPU, and a decline in ad revenue to 50mil from poorer macro conditions. By 2027, this would only add up to just $75mil of total revenue ($50mil + $20mil). Net margins could also slip to just 10%, and EPS fall to just $0.68, accounting for 11mil shares outstanding after buybacks. Giving it an 8x multiple, would lead to ~$5.4 in target price. This means there would be a ~33% downside.

In summary, this is an asymmetrical setup where the upside (3x) vastly outweighs the downside (~33%). The bull case hinges on the company proving to retain and grow its customer base. Moreover, even if it fails, the company has a good balance sheet with its negative net debt.

Risk

Some of the key risks to our thesis are that the paid membership strategy may not yield the conversion expected. For instance, TZOO fails to demonstrate enough exclusive value to its paying customers, the members would leave the platform altogether, and ad revenue would also be impacted. There is also competition risk from Expedia or Google, which may have better deal offerings or targeted marketing to reduce TZOO's appeal.

Also, changes in data privacy laws (like stricter e-privacy and cookie restrictions) could also make it harder for TZOO to acquire new members through digital marketing.

Conclusion

I believe TZOO offers a very compelling asymmetric setup where the company has good fundamentals, but the market is overly focused on short-term margin pressure. The Q2 and Q3 2025 results confirmed that earning softness was due to reinvestment into paid membership growth and not structural weakness. I see a 3-year target price of $24, implying an IRR of >60%. TZOO is a BUY at these levels.

Editor's Note: This article covers one or more microcap stocks. Please be aware of the risks associated with these stocks.

data.title: Exxon Mobil Continues To Benefit From Advantaged Upstream
data.description:
Exxon Mobil (XOM) is an almost $500 billion company, making it one of the largest publicly traded energy companies in the world. The company has continued to see record production from both the Permian Basin and Guyana, as the combined subsets have crossed 2 million barrels/day. As we'll see throughout this article, that makes Exxon Mobil a valuable investment in an expensive market.

Exxon Mobil Competitive Performance

Exxon Mobil is consistently ramping up competitive performance.

The company YTD is at more than 4.7 million barrels/day in production at more than 50% in advantaged assets. The company's earnings per barrel are more than $11/barrel. That's impressive to begin with. Going into 2030, Exxon Mobil is planning aggressive growth, to ~5.4 million barrels/day with more than 60% advantaged assets.

That will add more than 30% in annual cash flow for the company without requiring a substantial ramp in capex. From a product solutions standpoint, the company expects cash flow to almost triple as volumes go up, but the company benefits even more from quality sales. Company-wide, it will do this all while saving cash.

The company's production growth will be supported by cutting edge global projects. That includes new developments in Guyana, where the company is continuing to bring new FPSOs online. Exxon Mobil has a 45% working interest in Guyana, which will continue as production ramps up. At the same time, the company is continuing to ramp up low-cost production in the Permian Basin.

Exxon Mobil Financial Results

Financially, Exxon Mobil has continued to perform incredibly well, as the company's low-cost assets have continued to perform.

Exxon Mobil had $7.5 billion in GAAP earnings in the quarter along with $14.8 billion in CFFO. The company spent $8.6 billion in cash capex, with $6.2 billion in FCF. That's roughly $25 billion in annualized FCF, or a more than 5% FCF yield. The company has continued to maintain an incredibly low net debt-to-capital, giving it lots of financial freedom.

The company has continued to generate high single-digit shareholder returns, with an almost 3.5% dividend yield and continued share buybacks.

Exxon Mobil continues to do well in varied price environments. Crude prices are sitting near the 10-year 2010-2019 average despite a major downturn. Natural gas prices have benefited from high-energy demand, and we expect them to continue doing well. Refining margins sit in the middle, and chemical margins remain weak.

Overall though the company has the margins to continue lofty returns.

Exxon Mobil Shareholder Return Potential

At the same time, Exxon Mobil's shareholder returns are expected to remain strong.

As we discussed above, FCF remains strong despite continued lofty investment into its business. The company's guidance above indicates upstream earnings alone growing from just under $19 billion to more than $25 billion by 2030. At the same time, we expect the company's remaining earnings to continue their growth.

That combination will enable Exxon Mobil to ramp up shareholder returns at a time when energy is in higher demand than ever and the company has an irreplaceable portfolio of assets.

Thesis Risk

The largest risk to our thesis is crude oil prices. WTI prices are just a hair over $60/barrel, and Brent is in the mid-$60s/barrel. While Exxon Mobil is profitable at these levels, at a more than 5% free cash flow yield, the company still needs future growth to justify its valuation. That's a risk in an economy struggling with tariffs.

Conclusion

Exxon Mobil's earnings show that the company remains a profitable giant at a time of high-energy demand. The company has an almost $490 billion market capitalization with an almost 3.5% dividend yield and share buybacks that are even larger than its dividend. Despite that, the company maintains a manageable net-debt portfolio.

Exxon Mobil is continuing to aggressively grow. The company has seen surprisingly good results from Guyana and the Permian Basin, pushing production to almost 4.8 million barrels/day. The company expects production to ramp up further from that time, crossing 5 million barrels/day shortly.

That makes Exxon Mobil a valuable investment. Let us know your thoughts in the comments below.

data.title: Autolus: Good Product, But Tricky Market Dynamics (Rating Downgrade)
data.description:
Investment Overview

I last covered the United Kingdom-headquartered, commercial-stage biotech company Autolus (AUTL) for Seeking Alpha in June, assigning the stock a Buy rating. I also gave the stock a Buy rating in a note published in September last year, and in February 2024, and another back in August 2021.

How have those calls worked out? Shares are down >75% since my 2021 note, down 70% since my February 2024 note, down >60% since my September 2024 note, and down 34% since my note published in June.

Not a great track record, then, although during this period - on 8th November, 2024, in fact - Autolus secured its first commercial approval from the Food and Drug Administration ("FDA"), for its candidate obecabtagene autoleucel, a CD19-directed, genetically modified autologous T cell immunotherapy, now branded as Aucatzyl, in the indication of adults with relapsed or refractory B-cell precursor acute lymphoblastic leukemia ("ALL").

The approval of this therapy did nothing to arrest a bear run on stock that saw stock reach a low of <$1.5 in May this year, however, and although shares recovered to trade at >$2.5 in August, picking up the story today, they are priced at $1.5, which gives Autolus a market cap valuation of just $400m.

As I wrote in my last note, my buy calls were based on analysis of data from pivotal studies of Aucatzyl that suggested a "best-in-class" profile - below is an overview of the drug and its "unique" mechanism of action ("MoA") as provided by Autolus in a corporate presentation:

Now let's consider the data that helped secure Aucatzyl's approval:

As I wrote in my last post on Autolus, its data sets:

seemingly establish AUCATZYL as the best-in-class treatment in its field. Gilead Sciences, Inc. (GILD) Tecartus was approved to treat B-ALL in 2021, earning revenues of >$400m last year, based on a 65% complete remission and 13.6 months DoR. AUCATZYL's two data sets average out at a slightly superior CR rate and superior median DoR.

Autolus notes in its 2024 annual report/10-K filing that:

There are two direct in class competitors to AUCATZYL approved for the treatment of adult patients with r/r B-ALL: the autologous CAR therapies Tecartus and Kymriah. Tecartus is approved for use in adult B-ALL and Kymriah is approved for use in adolescents and young adults, (i.e., patients up to the age of 25). We believe obe-cel has a differentiated safety profile and shows potential for longer term outcomes when compared to these current approved therapies.

In summary, then, my point is that despite delivering on the promises made back in 2021 to secure approval for a cell therapy - besides the US, Aucatzyl has subsequently won approvals in the UK and EU - and designing and building a state-of-the-art manufacturing facility in the UK - the market has remained nonplussed.

A few days ago, another UK based biotech company, Adaptimmune, which had secured FDA approval for an engineered T-cell therapy, Teclera, to treat synovial sarcoma and myxoid liposarcoma, announced its delisting from the Nasdaq. The company previously sold Teclera to US WorldMeds, having exhausted its own funding, being unable to make its drug commercially successful.

Is there a danger something similar could happen to Autolus? In this note I'll cover some recent developments at the company, and explain why, although Autolus stock may not be emitting "screaming buy" signals at present, I believe the company can survive, and potentially even thrive long-term - but not so much in the near-term, given some difficult headwinds.

Autolus, Recent Updates - Q2 Earnings: Sales Impress, But Regulatory Issues Undermine Profitability

In my last note I covered Autolus' Q1 earnings, which saw Aucatzyl earn $9m of revenues, and the company report a net loss of $(70.2m), or $(0.26) per share, and a cash position of ~$500m.

Autolus reported Q2 earnings on August 12th (Q3 results are due 12th November). Aucatzyl product revenue came to $20.9m. Management noted that 46 authorised treatment centres in the US are now online (the process of being treated with Aucatzyl involves T-cell collection via leukapheresis, lymphodepleting chemotherapy, two infusions ten days apart, followed by monitoring for at least 14 days at the healthcare facility), and that:

Patient access to AUCATZYL continues to increase, with coverage secured for greater than 90% of total U.S. medical lives.

Autolus reported a cost of sales figure of $24.4m, R&D expenses of $27.4m, and SG&A expenses of $30.3m. Loss from operations came to $(61.2m), while net loss came to $(47.9m). Cash and equivalents came to $454.3m.

As things stand, then, the market values Autolus' business at less that its available cash, which is fairly damning in terms of its belief that Autolus can turn Aucatzyl into a successful commercial product.

That's understandable in many ways - besides Adaptimmune, Bluebird Bio is another company that developed multiple approved cell therapies, including Lyfgenia, to treat sickle cell disease, but could not make them work financially - Bluebird was taken private earlier this year for a fraction of what it was once worth.

On the Q2 earnings call, Autolus was unable to provide a timeline for when the business may become gross profitable. Aucatzyl is an expensive therapy, costing ~$525k, which is substantially more than Gilead Sciences (GILD) Tecartus, which costs ~$425k, but less than Novartis (NVS) Kymriah, which costs $580k.

While Pharma giants like Gilead and Novartis can absorb the losses associated with the early commercial launch of a product, thanks to the tens of billions of dollars they earn from other products, Autolus must operate under much more restrictive financial conditions, and this is a problem most keenly felt in Europe - the likes of Bluebird have formerly pulled their cell therapies from Europe after being unable to agree on pricing.

With that said, with the Trump administration now attempting to implement a most favoured nation ("MFN") approach to drug pricing in the US, i.e., Americans pay no more for their prescription drugs than whichever nation charges the least, matters become yet more complicated for Autolus.

Formerly, the company may have seen the US as its most lucrative market, but MFN, and the Trump administration's threat to introduce tariffs on pharma imports from overseas, adds a further layer of uncertainty.

On the Q2 earnings call, Autolus' CEO Dr. Christian Itin, spoke at length about the problems Europe has valuing drugs and their benefit, noting that:

as a consequence, we've seen a substantial proportion of cell and gene therapy products actually not being launched in Europe. There's something like 8 out of 18 that were not launched. So that's the backdrop. So we're going to do this very methodically, going to go through country by country and are navigating that.

In summary, then, it's hard to state with confidence that Autolus can make a profit selling Aucatzyl in the ALL setting in the US, or Europe. On the earnings call, the idea of patients traveling to the UK for treatment was discussed, although for a company attempting to make its drug available in as many localities as possible to attract patients, this may not be a viable long-term solution.

Expanding The Indications for Aucatzyl

One solution that Autolus is working on is turning Aucatzyl, or obe-cel, into a "pipeline in a product" i.e. secure approval for the therapy in other indications besides the narrow indication of ALL, where analysts have speculated the drug could earn peak revenues of ~$300m.

As we can see above, Autolus does have multiple studies ongoing. A pediatric ALL approval would increase the addressable market, and as we can see above, pediatric data is expected before the end of this year.

There are multiple early stage programs ongoing too, it seems; however, the company's main goal appears to be establishing obe-cel as an effective therapy for autoimmune diseases.

As we can see, studies in lupus and progressive multiple sclerosis ("MS") are ongoing, and there is evidence - from landmark studies conducted by Dr. Georg Schett - that cell therapies can be adapted to treat autoimmune diseases. With that said, despite several companies - Cabaletta Bio (CABA), Kyverna Therapeutics (KYTX), Bristol Myers Squibb (BMY) attempting to develop such therapies, no one has yet been able to replicate the success of Dr. Schett.

Autolus will dose first patients in studies in lupus and MS and present a Phase 1 study design in Systemic Lupus Erythematosus ("SLE") before the end of this year, management has promised, and signs of early success could prove a major upside catalyst for the company, but we must acknowledge that these programs are speculative and may be as likely to fail as they are to succeed.

Looking Ahead - Am I Upholding My Buy Rating On Autolus Stock Given Recent Developments?

As discussed, the quality of Autolus' therapy has been proven in clinical studies, and established Aucatzyl as arguably the best treatment for relapsed or refractory patients with acute lymphoblastic leukemia. Unlike Tecartus or Kymriah, the FDA has not required a risk evaluation and mitigation strategy ("REMS") program for the therapy, although it does come with a black box warning for the excessive immune response called cytokine release syndrome.

I noted in my last post that longer-term data from the FELIX study was due imminently, and could open the door for further approvals, and that data was summarised in the Q2 earnings release as follows:

Autolus presented updated long-term data from the FELIX study in adult patients with r/r B-ALL in an oral presentation at the 2025 European Hematology Association (EHA) Congress in June. For patients with a response, the updated median duration of response (mDOR) is now 42.5 months.

At the updated median follow up of 32.8 months, 38.4% of responders were in ongoing remission without consolidative stem cell therapy or other therapies (versus the previously reported 40% at a median follow-up of 21.5 months).

The 24-month probability of Event Free Survival was 43%, and the Overall Survival was 46%, with a further consolidating long-term plateau observed. No new safety signals or Grade ≥3 secondary malignancies were observed at the extended follow-up. These results suggest that obe-cel may be a durable treatment option for some patients with r/r B-ALL.

Five year Tecartus data showed an OS rate of 40% at four years, so there is arguably not much to choose between the two therapies, but Tecartus is also approved for Mantle Cell Lymphoma - frankly, I wonder if Autolus would be better off attempting to secure a similar label expansion as opposed to conducting its "moonshot" autoimmune studies. We may also note that Kymriah - $200m of revenues in 1H25 - is approved to treat B-cell lymphoma and follicular lymphoma, besides ALL.

Since Autolus joined the Nasdaq in 2018, raising ~$150m at $17 per share, the company has done many things right, in my view, but aside from a brief period in early 2024 when its biologics license application requesting approval for obe-cel was accepted by the FDA, and the company announced a $200m investment from BioNTech (BNTX), to co-develop and commercialize CAR-T cell therapies, when shares spiked >$7, it has been pretty much all downhill for the share price.

It may not be fair, but it is the reality, and I am not sure I see this changing in the near-to-medium term, due to the current uncertainty around drug pricing both in Europe and the US. For a company selling an expensive therapy in a relatively niche indication, competing against two incumbents with a similar safety and efficacy profile, this is a tricky scenario.

Autolus reported cash and equivalents of $123.8m as of the end of Q2, and marketable securities of $330m, therefore, given its net loss in 1H25 was $115m, its funding runway could be exhausted by early 2027. Autolus therefore finds itself under pressure to raise more funding, which could be difficult with its shares trading at such a low value. In its Q2 earnings press release, management states that

Autolus estimates that, with its current cash and cash equivalents and marketable securities, the Company is well capitalized to drive the launch and commercialization of obe-cel in r/r B-ALL and to obtain data in the LN pivotal trial and MS Phase 1 trial.

Autolus' accumulated deficit now stands at $1.2bn, which is an eye-watering sum, but one that has produced a strong product in Aucatzyl. I am quite impressed by the Q2 revenue figure and hopeful we will see it climb higher in Q3, but in other areas - cash consumption, speculative autoimmune studies, and early-stage research programs—I am less convinced. For example, based on a nine-month net loss, I have no choice but to downgrade my Buy rating to a Hold.

The problems Autolus faces today, which I have tried to outline in this post, are hopefully not terminal, but the headwinds are fairly strong at this time, and that makes me think Autolus can survive, but not thrive, in the near-to-medium term.

If I were management, I'd be looking to focus primarily on taking market share from Tecartus/Kymriah, and securing similar label expansions, whilst trying to engage in some cost-cutting, but hopefully, a momentous readout for the autoimmune program next year will allow the company to raise funds, and justify the additional R&D spend.

In terms of its upcoming Q3 earnings, the most important number will be the Aucatzyl revenue figure - management has not provided any specific guidance, but a beat on analysts' expectations would give it some breathing space. It's possible the company may tease some pediatric ALL data too - initial data has been promised in 2H25 - which could be another share price needle moving update.

data.title: 5 Relatively Secure And Cheap Dividend Stocks, Yields Up To 8% (Nov. 2025)
data.description:
************

Author's Note: This is our monthly series on Dividend Stocks, usually published in the first week of every month. We scan the universe of roughly 7,500 stocks listed and traded on U.S. exchanges and use our proprietary filtering criteria to select five relatively safe stocks that may be trading cheaper compared to their historical valuations. Some of the sections in the article, like "Selection Process/Methodology," are repeated each month with few changes and are presented in "italics." This is intentional as well as unavoidable, as this is necessary for the new readers to be able to conceptualize the process. Regular readers of this series could skip such sections to avoid repetitiveness and jump to the section titled "Selection of the Top 50". Readers can also read a more detailed explanation of the goals and the selection process in our blog post here.

************

Introduction and Market Summary:

The market has been making new all-time highs almost on a regular basis. In fact, the S&P500 has already crossed 6875 on Monday (10/27/2025) and is close to 6900 as we write this. It is only about 100 points short of the SPX7000 level that is psychologically important. The most recent rally has been powered by the hopes of further interest rate cuts by the Fed before the year's end (with one 25-basis-point cut already announced today) and the strong start of the earnings season. We did expect the market to cross the SPX7000 level by the year-end, but it appears we might get that much sooner.

You can see the current odds of the Fed's next rate cut here on the CME FedWatchTool website.

Also, this week, President Trump is meeting with the Chinese President to resolve the trade frictions between the two largest economies. The meeting is scheduled for Thursday. Even though the outcomes are not yet known (at the time of writing), the market does not seem to be overly concerned.

Further, five of the Magnificent Seven companies are due to release their earnings this week. This may be the make-or-break moment for the market for the rest of the year. If there is any disappointment of any sort from these tech giants, we might see a quick retrenchment. The big question now is what happens after SPX7000. Will the rally continue, or are we already at the peak?

It is always good to have some idea of where the markets and the broader economy may be headed. Even so, we believe markets are always unpredictable, and it is not possible to catch the exact bottom (or the peak). So, it is best to invest regularly and consistently in good, solid dividend-paying stocks when their valuations are reasonable or attractive.

This month, we highlight three groups with five stocks each that have an average dividend yield (as a group) of 4.1%, 5.3%, and 7.9%, respectively. The first list is for conservative and risk-averse investors, while the second is for investors seeking higher yields but still wanting relatively safe dividends. The third group is for yield-hungry investors but comes with an elevated risk, and we urge investors to exercise caution.

The Selection Process:

Goals and Objectives:

The main goal of this series of articles is to shortlist and highlight companies that have a solid history of paying and raising dividends. In addition, we demand that these companies support strong fundamentals, carry low debt, and are offered at a relatively cheaper valuation. These DGI stocks are not going to make anyone rich overnight, but if your goal is to attain financial freedom by owning stocks that would grow dividends over time, meaningfully and sustainably, then you are at the right place. These lists are not necessarily recommendations to buy, but a shortlist of probable candidates for further research. Besides, we think each month, if nothing else, this analysis is able to highlight some nuggets that would have otherwise skipped our attention.

Every month, we start with roughly 7,500 stocks that are listed and traded on U.S. exchanges, including over-the-counter (OTC) networks. Using our filtering criteria, the initial list is quickly narrowed to roughly 700 stocks, mostly dividend-paying and dividend-growing. From thereon, by using various data elements, including dividend history, payout ratios, revenue growth, debt ratios, EPS growth, etc., we calculate a "Dividend Quality Score" for each stock that measures the relative safety and sustainability of the dividend. In addition to dividend safety, we also seek cheaper valuations. We also demand that the selected companies have an established business model, solid dividend history, manageable debt, and investment-grade credit rating.

Notes: 1) Please note that when we use the term "safe" in relation to stocks and investments, it should be interpreted as "relatively safe" because nothing is absolutely safe in investing. Even though we present only 5 to 10 stocks in our final list, one should have 15-20 stocks at a minimum in a well-diversified portfolio.

2) All tables in this article are created by the author unless explicitly specified. The stock data have been sourced from various sources such as Seeking Alpha, Yahoo Finance, GuruFocus, Morningstar, and CCC-List (Dividend Radar).

Criteria to Shortlist:

  • Market cap > $7 billion (some exceptions can be made)
  • Dividend yield > 1.0% (some exceptions are made to include high-quality but lower-yielding companies)
  • Daily average volume > 100,000
  • Dividend growth past five years >= 0.

By applying the above criteria, we got around 600 companies.

Narrowing Down the List

As a first step, we would like to eliminate stocks that have less than five years of dividend history. Also, since we want a lot of flexibility and wider choice at this initial stage, we include some companies that pay dividends lower than the S&P500 but otherwise have a stellar dividend record and growing dividends at a fast pace.

However, so far in this list, we have demanded five or more years of consistent dividend growth. But what if a company had a very stable record of dividend payments but did not increase the dividends from one year to another? At times, some of these companies are foreign-based companies, and due to currency fluctuations, their dividends may appear to have been cut in U.S. dollars, but in reality, that may not be true at all when looked at in the actual currency of reporting. At times, we may provide some exceptions when a company may have cut the dividend in the past, but otherwise, it looks compelling.

We now import the various data elements from many sources and assign weights based on different criteria as listed below:

  • Current yield: Indicates the yield based on the current price.
  • Dividend growth history (number of years of dividend growth): This provides information on how many years a company has paid and increased dividends on a consistent basis. For stocks under the category 'B' (defined above), we consider the total number of consecutive years of dividends paid rather than the number of years of dividend growth.
  • Payout ratio: This indicates how comfortably the company can pay the dividend from its earnings. We prefer this ratio to be as low as possible, which would indicate the company's ability to grow the dividend in the future. This ratio is calculated by dividing the dividend amount per share by the EPS (earnings per share). The cash-flow payout ratio is calculated by dividing the dividend amount paid per share by the cash flow generated per share.
  • Past three-year and 5-year dividend growth: Even though it's the dividend growth rate from the past, this does indicate how fast the company has been able to grow its earnings and dividends in the recent past. The recent past is the best indicator that we have to know what to expect in the next few years.
  • EPS growth (average of previous five years of growth and expected next five years' growth): As the earnings of a company grow, more than likely, dividends will grow accordingly. We will take into account the actual EPS growth of the previous five years and the estimated EPS growth for the next five years. We will add the two numbers and assign weights.
  • Chowder number: So, what's the Chowder number? This number has been named after the well-known SA author Chowder, who first coined and popularized this factor. This number is derived by adding the current yield and the past five years' dividend growth rate. A Chowder number of "12" or more ("8" for utilities) is considered good.
  • Debt/equity ratio: This ratio will tell us about the company's debt load in relation to its equity. We all know that too much debt can lead to major problems, even for well-known companies. The lower this ratio, the better it is. Sometimes, we find this ratio to be negative or unavailable, even for well-known companies. This can happen for a myriad of reasons and is not always a reason for concern. This is why we use this ratio in combination with the debt/asset ratio (covered next).
  • Debt/asset ratio: This ratio will tell us about the debt load in relation to the company's total assets. In almost all cases, this ratio would be lower than the debt/equity ratio. Also, this ratio is important because, for some companies, the debt/equity ratio is not a reliable indicator.
  • S&P's credit rating: This is the credit rating assigned by the rating agency S&P Global and is indicative of the company's ability to service its debt. This rating can be obtained from the S&P website.
  • PEG ratio: This is also called the price/earnings-to-growth ratio. The PEG ratio is considered to be an indicator if the stock is overvalued, undervalued, or fairly priced. A lower PEG may indicate that a stock is undervalued. However, PEG for a company may differ significantly from one reported source to another, depending on which growth estimate is used in the calculation. Some use past growth, while others may use future expected growth.
  • Distance from 52-week high: We want to select companies that are good, solid companies, but also are trading at cheaper valuations currently. They may be cheaper due to some temporary down cycle, or some combination of bad news, or simply having a bad quarter. This criterion will help bring such companies (with a cheaper valuation) near the top as long as they excel in other criteria as well. This factor is calculated as (current price - 52-week high) / 52-week high.
  • Sales or Revenue growth: This is the average growth rate in annual sales or revenue of the company over the last five years. A company can only grow its earnings power as long as it can grow its revenue. Sure, it can grow the earnings by cutting costs, but that can't go on forever.

Selection Of The Top 50

Downloadable Dataset: Below, we provide a link to the table with relevant data on nearly 500 stocks. Readers can download this table for further analysis. Please note that the table is sorted by "Total Weight" or "Quality Score."

File-for-export_-_5_Secure_DGI_-_NOV_2025.xlsx

We will first bring down the list (of 400-plus names) to roughly 50 names by automated criteria, as listed below. In the second step, which is mostly manual and subjective, we will bring the list down to about 15.

  • Step 1: First, take the top 20 names from the above table (based on total weight or quality score). At times, some industry segments tend to get overcrowded at the top, so we take the top two (or three) and ignore the rest.
  • Step 2: As a second step, we will take the top 10 names based on the highest dividend yield. When it comes to dividend yield, some of the industry segments tend to be overcrowded. So, we will take the top two (or a maximum of three) names from any single industry segment.
  • Step 3: Now, we will sort our list based on five-year dividend growth (highest at the top) and select the top 10 names.
  • Step 4: We will now consider more recent dividend growth, as that is more indicative of the company's future growth. We will sort our list based on 3-year dividend growth (highest at the top) and select the top 10 names.
  • Step 5: We also want to give priority to stocks that are rated highest in terms of credit rating. So, we will sort the list based on the numerical weight of the credit rating and select the top 10 stocks with the best credit rating. Again, we are careful not to have too many names from the same sector.
  • Step 6: Lastly, as the name of the series suggests, we want to have some names that may be trading cheaper in comparison to their historical valuation. So, we select the top ten names with the highest discount. However, they could be trading cheap for just the wrong reasons, so we need to be careful that they meet our other quality criteria.

From the above steps, we now have a total of 70 names in our final consideration. However, the following stocks appeared more than once:

Stocks that appeared two times: ACN, ADP, AU, CAG, CI, CVE, GE, HWM, LYB, MSFT, OC, and WIT (12 duplicates).

Stocks that appeared three times: CIB (2 duplicates).

After removing eight duplicates, we are left with 56 (70-14) names.

Since we still have a very large list, we will remove names that have a low yield and not very great dividend growth. So, if the dividend yield was less than < 2.5% and the dividend growth (average of 5-year and 10-year) was less than 8%-10%, we would rather remove them at this stage.

So, we remove AMP and NFG. After removing them, we are left with 54 names.

Since there are still multiple names in each industry segment, we will keep a maximum of two or three names (from the top) from any one segment.

On this basis, we remove a total of 14 names: EMN, ACN, FMX, ACI, BBVA, TD, IBKR, MMC, NVO, UNH, CTRA, IMO, OKE, and PAG.

After we remove these 16 names, we are left with 40 (54-14) names.

The top names from each sector/industry segment are presented:

Financial Services, Banking, and Insurance:

Banks- Regional:

Banks- Major: (JPM)

Bank (Foreign) – (CIB)

Financial Services - Others: (ARCC), (AEG)

(CSL)

(CTAS), (NDSN), (TS), (GE)

(TFII), (UPS).

(VZ), (TU).

Healthcare:

Pharma: (JNJ), (MRK), (PFE).

Healthcare Insurance: (CI).

Software: (INTU), (MSFT), (WIT)

Semi-Conductor & Electronics: (TSM), (APH)

Energy Majors: (CVX)

Oil & Gas (prod. & exploration):

Pipelines/ Midstream: (HESM), (MPLX).

(AMH), (GLPI)

Final Step: Narrowing Down To Just Five Companies

In this step, we construct three separate lists of five stocks each, with different sets of goals, dividend income, and risk levels.

The lists are:

1) Relatively Safe (Low-yield) Dividend list,

2) Moderately High Dividend List,

3) Ultra High Dividend List, and

4) A combined list of the above three (duplicates removed).

Out of the top 40, we make our judgment calls to make these three lists, so basically, the selections are based on our research and perceptions. So, while most of the filtering until now was based on automated criteria, the last step is pretty much subjective. We try to make each of the three lists highly diversified among various sectors and industry segments, and try to ensure that the safety of dividends matches the overall risk profile of the group. We certainly encourage readers to do further research on the highlighted names.

Nonetheless, here are our three final lists for this month:

Table-1A: A-LIST (Conservative Income)

We think this set of five companies (in the A-List) would form a solid diversified group of dividend companies that would be appealing to income-seeking and conservative investors, including retirees and near-retirees. The average yield is 3.56%, which is more than 3x of what the S&P 500 pays. The average dividend history is 20 years. Also, all five companies have an excellent rating of 'A-' or higher. If you must need higher dividends, consider the B-List or the C-List, presented later.

As usual, we will provide a brief synopsis of each of the companies selected here; however, we will not go into too many details, as that will make the article unduly long.

INTU (Intuit Inc):

The current dividend yield of Intuit is very low at 0.70%, so it does not serve the purpose of retirees who may depend on dividends for their income. But the reason we include it in the A-list is due to its potential for dividend growth. The dividend growth has been 15% (or plus) for 3, 5, and 10-year periods. Its major premium products include TurboTax and QuickBooks.

Intuit appears to be firing on all cylinders and has achieved 20% revenue growth in the fourth quarter and 16% growth on a full-year basis, both beating management's own guidance. The operating margins have also been expanding nicely. There are some risks and competitive threats from free programs, such as the IRS's "Direct File" program. However, it poses only minimal risk to Intuit's business.

ADP (Automatic Data Processing):

ADP's yield is relatively low at 2.2%, but it is often considered a favorite of dividend investors, given the company's stability and reliability of the dividend and above-average dividend growth. It is relatively rare to find this company trading at cheaper valuations, except during deep market corrections. Morningstar rates the stock price just about 'fairly valued'. So, the shares are not cheap either, but still 10-15% below the 52-week high.

For dividend investors, the company offers a 50-year record of consistently growing dividends. The last increase was a 10% increase. The past 3-year and 5-year dividend growth has been impressive at roughly 14% and 11%, respectively. Even though the yield is low, we think relatively high growth should compensate for the low yield in the long run. It is being included in the A-list for its exceptional record of growing dividends and excellent credit rating.

TS (Tenaris S.A.):

Tenaris is headquartered in Luxembourg but has a lot of presence and manufacturing facilities in the U.S. The company manufactures and supplies steel pipes and related products & services for the energy sector, specifically in the drilling industry. Nearly 50% of the company's revenues come from North America, while 20% from South America. In fact, Europe contributes less than 10% of the company's revenue.

The company is currently facing a number of industry-specific headwinds due to the slowdown in the Oil industry, but it supports a very solid financial base with almost zero debt. Besides, it has a strong cash reserve of nearly $4 billion. It is a very shareholder-friendly company, and in the last year, it returned almost a billion dollars in the form of dividends and share buy-backs. Currently, the yield is very attractive at 6.25%.

CVX (CHEVRON):

CVX needs no introduction as an oil major and is probably one of the best investments in its sector for stable income. However, earnings and the share price of the company are obviously tied to the movement of the oil prices, which can fluctuate widely based on geopolitical situations of the day. That being said, the company provides relative safety, an excellent credit rating, stable business, and a reasonably high dividend yield for a large company. Chevron is known to be a low-cost producer with its breakeven price in the low to mid-40s.

Similar to previous months, we are including CVX in the A-list for reasons stated above. CVX currently offers a highly attractive dividend yield of close to 4.4%. The payout ratio is currently a bit high on an EPS basis and relatively low on a cash flow basis. The dividend growth has been a bit tepid over the years, but reasonable at 6% plus, considering the starting yield. The company maintains an excellent credit rating of 'AA' from S&P, which shows its financial strength.

VZ (Verizon):

Verizon has had a few tough years, at least since 2022. There was some respite in 2024, but the stock price has been pulled down once again to below $40. With the stock price once again under $40 a share, it should be treated as in buying territory. With the current prices, it is fairly undervalued, and it is nearly 25% below the fair value assigned by Morningstar. It supports a reasonably high dividend yield of close to 7.1%.

Obviously, the big negative with the company is its continued high debt burden. Even then, Verizon still remains a strong player among the three large telecom companies in the U.S., and it offers an attractive reward-to-risk ratio. With interest rates coming down, income-oriented stocks like VZ are likely to benefit.

MPLX (MPLX LP):

For the B-List and C-List, the dividend yield of Chevron is somewhat low. So, we replace it with MPLX LP, a highly attractive name from the midstream energy industry, mainly to elevate the yield. Please note that the company has a Partnership structure and issues a K-1 tax form (partnership income) instead of the usual 1099 in case of regular dividends.

We have covered MPLX multiple times in our previous articles in this monthly series. Hence, we will skip the details here. MPLX regularly features on our B-list and C-list due to its stable dividend growth and high yield. There are other good alternatives, such as Enterprise Products Partners (EPD) or Energy Transfer (ET).

ARCC (Ares Capital):

We are including Ares Capital in the B-list and the C-list. ARCC is one of the largest BDCs (Business Development Companies) in terms of market capitalization and net asset value. The company invests in small and medium-sized companies and has a diversified portfolio of investments in over 500 companies. Besides, ARCC has a proven record of performing reasonably well both in high and low-interest rate environments. Pricing and valuation-wise, it trades at a slight premium for being one of the largest in the BDC arena, and its stable dividend.

It generates a solid amount of NII (net Investment income), which currently exceeds well above the $1.2 billion mark on an annual basis. ARCC currently offers a highly attractive yield of roughly 9.6%.

It is apparent from the selections that this list (C-List) is for yield-hungry DGI investors. The yield goes up to 7.9%. However, please note that this list is not for conservative investors. As you can see, the average credit rating of this set of companies is much lower than the A-List or even the B-List. Dividends are moderately safe in this list, but not nearly as safe as in the A-List or B-list. At least a couple of companies in this list come with an elevated level of risk, as they are turnaround stories. We urge due diligence to determine if it would suit your personal situation. Nothing comes for free, so there will be more risk involved with this group. Even then, it's a diversified group spread among five different industry segments.

UPS (United Parcel Service):

UPS is one of two duopolies in the logistics sector in the US (the other one is FedEx). In fact, there are only three major multinational firms in the world: UPS, FedEx, and DHL (based in Europe). However, the company's share price has lost nearly 40% of its value during the last 52 weeks. Due to the falling share price, the dividend yield has gone up a lot (currently at 7.5%). At the same time, the payout ratio is uncomfortably high at over 80%. The negative sentiment is a combination of many factors. First, it is in the process of ramping down the Amazon package business, as the margins were very thin. Secondly, the tariff-related concerns, especially with the expiry of the tariff exemption on de-minimis packages, have added to the woes. Thirdly, the agreement negotiated by UPS with its employee unions in 2023 is proving to be expensive and driving wage cost inflation. The company is undertaking downsizing and cost-cutting initiatives; however, it is yet to be seen how successful they will be. On the positive side, UPS maintains a solid balance sheet and maintains an excellent credit rating of 'A' from the S&P. Its debt is relatively high but manageable. As per Morningstar, the share price is nearly 20% below its fair value, even after Morningstar lowered its fair-value estimates. The current yield of 7.5% is nearly two and a half times its long-term 5-year average of 3.1%. Even though the company has termed the dividend as "rock-solid" in the last earnings call, it is not reassuring when the payout ratio is reaching nearly 90% of earnings.

In a nutshell, the company is more of a turnaround story right now, and this is the high-risk, high-reward stock. However, we believe patient investors are likely to be rewarded as the shares appear to be at or near the bottom, but the execution risk remains.

Note: We would like to caution that each company comes with certain risks and concerns. Sometimes, these risks are real, but other times, they may be a bit overblown and temporary. So, it's always recommended to do further research and due diligence.

Conclusion:

In this article, we have presented three groups of dividend-paying stocks (five each) with different goals in mind to suit the varying needs of a wider audience. Even though the risk profile of each group is different, each group in itself is fairly balanced and diversified.

This month, the first group yields 4.1%, while the second group elevates the yield to 5.3%. We also presented a C-list for yield-hungry investors with a 7.9% yield. The combined group (all three lists combined with duplication removed) offers an even more diversified group with nine positions and a 5.9% yield.
